Financial services are actively undergoing digital transformation to enhance user experience while driving efficiency and innovation. Although bank executives all consider digital transformation a crucial factor for long-term success and have invested in modernizing IT infrastructure, only less than 10% according to Accenture have fully focused on transforming operations.

The demand for better digital experiences and customers’ desire for modernization are growing. Banking leaders need to consider three key factors to implement an effective digital transformation strategy, drive growth, and meet customer needs.

Customer Experience as a Key Competitive Differentiator

Customers expect speed, convenience, and seamless experiences when handling their money, yet Salesforce research shows that only 21% are satisfied with the digital experiences they receive.

Companies that invest in delivering the best customer experiences through digital services can differentiate themselves and better delight customers.

End users, whether consumers or businesses, do not care about what happens behind the scenes—they want experiences and services that simply work. To go further, by adding new digital services such as virtual cards, P2P payments, biometric identification, etc., banks can create greater distance from their competitors.

Back-End Operational Excellence is Critical

As important as front-end experiences are, back-end operations are what sustain and build customer relationships.

Value-added digital services that deliver operational excellence can enhance the customer experience through better customer service, improved security, and other capabilities.

Emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence can significantly improve how companies gain better visibility into their operations and customer base. Take data streams and management as an example. Many executives report being overwhelmed with information, yet about half admit struggling to analyze it, according to Paynearme research. While data is important, the insights derived from that data are the key to the decisions executives must make.

Maintaining digital records of customer information, transaction history, spending behavior, and other metrics—and applying AI to analyze and make decisions can help companies deliver better services and protect their end users. They can streamline customer service, for example, by immediately retrieving relevant information and providing near real-time solutions, or by automatically analyzing spending behavior and location data to prevent potential fraudsters.

Cloud Services Can Build Flexibility and Scalability

The use of cloud services can provide banks and other financial service providers the flexibility to develop services over time, easily integrate third-party services when needed, and scale their business as the market evolves.

For example, in fintech, cloud platforms allow companies to deliver configurable features and the convenience of scaling and adjusting services as their customers grow and evolve. Especially when platforms are developer-friendly, features can be seamlessly integrated through third-party APIs otherwise, building them in-house would require extensive resources.

Nearly all (95%) of PwC’s cloud banking survey respondents said they will be fully cloud-based within two years, but only 38% have scaled across their entire enterprise. The challenge of modernizing company platforms may be the bottleneck for innovation.

Banks can differentiate with digital services, but it is essential to fully understand your customers to ensure you are defining the right digital transformation roadmap and priorities. By focusing on modern, customer-centric UX supported by seamless and efficient back-end operations, and leveraging cloud services to drive efficiency and provide future resilience, companies can deliver better customer experiences and innovate faster and more effectively.
